Doing things upside down doesn't work with us. We aren't made in a buoyant medium but our blood flows down into our feet which are made to handle the higher pressure being on the bottom so we don't feel it.

We can be different but it's being wrong that we should never be.

As an ex Aquariun shop owner, I have observed this and there is little to be concerned about as this fish is a specie of Corydora that has the swim bladder centrally in their body to help stay afloat in many positions, even upside down so that they can feed under leaves of plants, rocks, ornaments and timber. Sometimes they spend long time swimming upside down because they are what they are and don't care whether they are right side up or upside down but when rummaging on the sand at the bottom, they return back right side up. Other times they may have an infected of the air sack and need to surface to gulp air to stabilize the bladder,  or may have an infection caused by virus or pathogen in the water. They're gorgeous to watch.

Thank you for highlighting one of my all time favorite fish! The upside down catfish (genus Synodontis) are awesome fish that are fun to watch, fun to keep, and have tons of personality. The species you highlighted in this video stays relatively small and is easy to care for, so they are appropriate for novice fishkeepers. They can make a wonderfully unique addition to a community tank!

Within the Genus Synodontis, there are 131 extant species, 7 of which are referred to as Upside-Down Fish. They belong to a larger family of catfish, the Mochokidae, all freshwater, all endemic to Africa. Within the Mochokidae are also the Squeaker Catfish. Species Synodontis nigriventis is native to the Congo basin and the IUCN lists its conservation status as Least Concern.
